content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Elizabeth Buchanan: I was born in Vienna, Austria, to a family that valued education and culture deeply. My father was a professor of philosophy, and my mother was a translator. We moved to the United States when I was nine, settling in Portland, Oregon, where I grew up. Life wasn't easy at first—we had to adjust to a new language, new customs, and a different way of life. My parents worked hard to give me and my younger brother a good education, and I was always encouraged to pursue my interests. I was fascinated by languages and Eastern philosophies from a young age, which is why I eventually converted to Buddhism in my early twenties. I went to college in Oregon, studied comparative religion, and later earned my graduate degree in cultural studies. After college, I married my husband, David, who is a software developer. We have two children, and I've chosen to stay home with them while also volunteering at a local community center. It's been a different kind of work, but I find purpose in it. Looking back, my journey has been one of adaptation, growth, and finding balance between my roots and the life I've built here.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Yes, there was a moment that felt like a crossroads, though I didn't realize it at the time. I was around twenty-two, finishing my undergraduate degree in comparative religion. I had been raised in a very structured, academic environment, and I had always been expected to follow a traditional path—perhaps becoming a professor or a researcher. But I was also deeply drawn to the spiritual and philosophical aspects of Buddhism, which I had studied on my own for years. I had the opportunity to take a semester abroad in Kyoto, Japan, to study at a Buddhist monastery. It was a chance to immerse myself in the practice, to live simply, and to reflect on my purpose. My parents were hesitant—they worried about the stability of such a path, and I was worried about leaving my brother behind, who was still in high school. But I went. That semester changed everything. I returned with a clearer sense of who I was and what I wanted. I didn't go back to the academic path I had been on. Instead, I pursued a graduate degree in cultural studies, focusing on the intersection of Eastern philosophies and Western societies. That decision led me to meet my husband, who was working on a tech project that involved cultural adaptation in global software design. I think that crossroads was the moment I truly began to define my own path, rather than following someone else's expectations.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way most people might expect. I wasn't making a decision in a moment of clarity or certainty—I was making a decision in the midst of uncertainty. I had spent so much of my life following expectations, whether my parents', my culture's, or even my own academic ambitions. But when I was in Kyoto, I realized that I didn't want to be someone who just studied these things from a distance. I wanted to live them. So I made the choice to shift my focus, even though I didn't know exactly where it would take me. I think that's what makes it so meaningful to me—it wasn't a sudden revelation, but a slow, deliberate turning away from one path and toward another, even when the new path wasn't fully visible yet.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Yes, I think someone or something could have helped, though I don't know if I would have accepted it at the time. My parents were supportive in their own way, but they were also deeply rooted in their own expectations for me. I remember talking to a professor of mine, Dr. Langston, who had a way of asking questions that made you look at your own assumptions. He once asked me, 'What would you do if you weren't afraid of being wrong?' That question stuck with me. I think if I had been more open to guidance like that, or if I had found a mentor who understood the spiritual path as deeply as I did, it might have made the transition easier. But in the end, I think I needed to go through that uncertainty on my own. It was a lonely path, but it was mine.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, David, is a software developer who grew up here in Portland. We met through a mutual friend during my graduate studies—actually, he was working on a project that involved designing user interfaces for cultural institutions, and I was assisting with the research side of it. We connected over our shared interest in how different cultures interact with technology. We married a few years after I finished my degree, and we have two children: a daughter, Clara, who's seven, and a son, Liam, who's four. I chose to stay home with them full-time, which has been both challenging and deeply fulfilling. I also volunteer at a local community center, where I help organize cultural exchange programs—something that ties back to my roots and my studies. It's a way for me to give back, to help others find the same kind of connection and understanding that I did when I was younger.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by choices—some obvious, others subtle. Reflecting on my story, I see how my early years in Vienna and the move to the U.S. laid the foundation for who I am today. The crossroads I faced in Kyoto was a pivotal moment, not just in terms of my career, but in how I began to define my own values and purpose. I realize now that even the uncertainty I felt back then was part of the process of growing into the person I am. It's also humbling to think about how much my parents and professors influenced me, even when I didn't fully recognize their impact at the time. Now, as I raise my children and volunteer in the community, I feel a deep connection to the lessons I've learned throughout my life. It's not just about where I came from or the paths I took—it's about how I continue to weave those experiences into the present, shaping both my family and my community.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Elizabeth Buchanan: My immediate family includes my parents, who still live in Vienna, and my younger brother, Marcus. We stay in touch through letters and video calls, though it's not as frequent as I'd like. My parents have always been proud of me, even if they didn't fully understand the path I chose. My brother, on the other hand, has always been more of a traditionalist—he became a lawyer here in the U.S. and has a family of his own now. We don't always see eye to eye, but I respect him deeply. He was the one who stayed behind when we moved to Portland, and I think he always felt like he was the one who had to hold things together while I was away in Kyoto. I carry that with me, and I try to make sure my children know that even when we take different paths, family is still the foundation that holds us together.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: There are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Aiko, a fellow student from my time in Kyoto. She was the one who encouraged me to stay for the full semester and really helped me navigate the cultural and spiritual aspects of life there. We remained in touch, and even though we live on opposite sides of the world now, she's someone I can always count on for deep conversations and support. Then there's my friend Rachel, who I met during my graduate studies here in Portland. She's a social worker, and she's been a huge influence on my decision to volunteer at the community center. She's the one who first introduced me to the idea of cultural exchange programs, and she's always pushing me to think about how I can use my background to help others. I also have a few close friends from my time in college, though life has taken us in different directions. Still, I feel lucky to have people in my life who have helped shape who I am, even if we don't see each other as often as I'd like.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Elizabeth Buchanan: I live in a neighborhood called Irvington, which is a bit more residential and quieter than the downtown areas of Portland. It's a mix of older homes and some newer developments, with a lot of trees and green spaces. There's a community garden nearby where I sometimes volunteer, and it's become a little hub for people to gather, share food, and talk about things that matter. The area has a diverse population—there are a lot of artists, teachers, and professionals who have chosen to live here because of the sense of community. I love that there are small cafes and bookstores, and that the streets are lined with big evergreen trees that make the place feel cozy even in the colder months. It's not perfect—like anywhere, there are challenges—but I feel like I'm part of something that's growing and evolving, which mirrors my own journey. It's a place where I can raise my children with a sense of stability, but also with the openness to explore and learn, just like I did when I was younger.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I feel quite safe here, though I think it's more about the sense of community than anything else. There's a kind of unspoken trust among neighbors, even if we don't know each other well. People look out for one another, and there's a general respect for the space we all share. I've never felt threatened or unsafe in Irvington, which is something I appreciate, especially as a mother. It's not just about physical safety—it's about feeling like this is a place where my children can grow up with a sense of belonging and security. That, to me, is the kind of safety that matters most.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Elizabeth Buchanan: Living here in Irvington has been a mix of quiet contentment and occasional challenges, but overall, it's a place that feels like home. One of the things I appreciate most is the sense of timelessness—the older homes have a character that feels rooted in history, and the community feels like it's been built with care. That said, there are moments when I feel the weight of the slower pace. As someone who once lived in a fast-paced academic environment and later in the tech world through my husband's work, I sometimes miss the energy of a more dynamic setting. But I've come to realize that the slower rhythm here allows me to be more present with my children, to notice the small things—the way the light filters through the trees in the morning, or how the community garden has become a place where people from different backgrounds come together. It's not without its struggles—like any neighborhood, there are issues with affordability and gentrification that I watch with concern. But I try to focus on the positive, on the fact that this place has given me the space to grow into the person I am today, and to raise my children in an environment that values connection, reflection, and community.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my current life is intertwined with the people and places that shape my daily existence. Talking about my family, especially my husband David and our children Clara and Liam, reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in the life I've built here in Portland. It's not just about the roles we play—being a mother, a wife, a volunteer—but about the quiet moments that make those roles meaningful. When I described my neighborhood, Irvington, and the sense of safety and community it offers, I felt a deep connection to the place that has become my home. It's a neighborhood that allows me to raise my children with care, to engage with others in meaningful ways, and to continue the work I started years ago with cultural exchange and understanding. The interview made me think about how much my past has shaped my present, and how the people and places I've chosen to surround myself with are not just parts of my life—they are the foundation of who I am now.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Elizabeth Buchanan: A typical week for me is a blend of routine and flexibility, shaped by the needs of my family and the work I do at the community center. Mornings usually start with the kids, getting them ready for school, making breakfast, and trying to find a few quiet moments for myself before the day gets too busy. On weekdays, I drop Clara off at school and spend some time volunteering—whether it's helping organize a cultural exchange event, teaching a language class, or just chatting with the other volunteers over coffee. After school, I pick her up, and we usually have some time together before Liam gets home from his daycare. Evenings are often spent helping with homework, reading, or playing games. On weekends, we try to get out and explore—sometimes we visit the local park, go to a museum, or have a picnic in the neighborhood. I also make time for meditation, which has become an important part of my daily life, especially since converting to Buddhism. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling a lot, but I've learned to find peace in the rhythm of it all, even when it's not perfect.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I don't have a traditional job in the way most people do, but I consider my role as a mother and volunteer to be my work. I spend most of my days at home with my children, which means my schedule is flexible but often full. I work at the community center a few days a week, usually in the mornings, helping with cultural programs and language classes. The rest of the time, I'm managing the household, which includes everything from cooking and cleaning to helping with homework and bedtime routines. I also dedicate time to my personal practice—meditation and reading, which help me stay grounded. While it's not the kind of work that comes with a paycheck or a title, I feel deeply fulfilled by it. It's a quieter kind of labor, but one that allows me to be present for my family and contribute to the community in a way that aligns with my values. I think of it as a kind of spiritual practice, too—one that requires patience, compassion, and a lot of listening.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Yes, there are a few other routines that shape my days. One of them is my morning meditation practice, which I try to do every day, even if it's just for ten minutes. It helps me start the day with a sense of calm and intention. I also have a small ritual of writing in a journal, where I reflect on the day ahead or jot down thoughts that come to me during the night. It's not always about big revelations—it's more about staying connected to myself and my values. Another thing I do is cook meals in bulk on the weekends, which helps me manage the week more easily. I love experimenting with different cuisines, especially ones I learned about during my time in Kyoto and through my studies. It's a way to bring a little piece of the world into my kitchen and share it with my family. I also make it a point to read a little every evening, usually something related to philosophy or spirituality, which keeps me grounded and reminds me of why I chose the path I did. These routines, though simple, are what help me navigate the busyness of everyday life with a sense of purpose and balance.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Elizabeth Buchanan: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness into the moments I spend with my children. I used to think of meditation as something I did alone, but now I try to bring that same intentionality into our family time. For example, before we start our day, I've begun guiding the kids in a short breathing exercise, something I learned during my time in Kyoto. It's not always perfect—Liam still gets distracted, and Clara sometimes rolls her eyes—but I've noticed that these small moments of presence have started to shift the tone of our mornings. I also started a new tradition of having a family meal together every Sunday, which has been a nice way to slow down and connect, especially with how busy our week can get. It's a small change, but it's one that feels meaningful, and I'm grateful for the little ways I can weave mindfulness into the rhythm of everyday life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Elizabeth Buchanan: A typical weekday during the school year for my children starts early—usually around 7:30 a.m. Clara, who's in second grade, has a structured morning routine that includes getting dressed, having breakfast, and packing her backpack with her books and supplies. She walks to school with a friend, which I think helps her feel more connected to her peers. Liam, who's in preschool, has a slightly more flexible schedule, but we try to get him up and out by 8:30. After school, Clara comes home and usually has a snack, then either does homework or plays outside with the neighborhood kids. She's involved in a few after-school activities—like a weekly art class and a club for young readers. Liam, on the other hand, spends his afternoons at a local daycare where they have structured play and learning time. In the evenings, we try to have a family dinner together, which has become a really important ritual for us. It's not always easy with the kids' schedules, but I think it's something that helps us stay connected, even in the busiest of days.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life is shaped by the people, routines, and values I've come to hold dear. Talking about my family, my neighborhood, and my routines has reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the life I've built here in Irvington. It's not just about the roles I play—as a mother, a volunteer, or a meditator—but about the quiet, meaningful moments that give those roles purpose. My days may not be filled with grand gestures or dramatic changes, but they are filled with intention, connection, and the small, steady rhythms that keep me grounded. I see now how my past—my childhood in Vienna, my time in Kyoto, my studies and choices—has all led me to this present moment, where I can raise my children with love, contribute to my community, and continue to grow in ways that feel true to who I am. It's a life that isn't always easy, but it's one that feels deeply right.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Elizabeth Buchanan: My health has been generally good, though like most people, I've had my share of ups and downs. I try to maintain a balanced lifestyle with regular exercise, a mindful diet, and plenty of rest. I walk with the kids most days, which keeps me active, and I've started doing yoga a few times a week, something I picked up during my time in Kyoto. I also pay attention to what I eat, trying to incorporate more whole foods and less processed stuff—something that's become especially important since I've been more involved in community work and want to be present for my family. I do have some chronic issues with my back from years of sitting during my studies and early career, but I manage it with regular stretching and occasional visits to a chiropractor. Overall, I feel lucky to be in good health, and I try to approach it as part of my spiritual practice—honoring the body as a vessel for the mind and spirit. I also make sure to schedule regular check-ups and listen to my body when it needs rest, which has become more important as I've gotten older and more aware of how deeply health affects every part of life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Elizabeth Buchanan: What makes it easy to stay healthy, for me, is the rhythm of daily life that I've built around my family and community. The walks with the kids, the yoga, and the mindfulness practices have become natural parts of my day, not something I have to force myself to do. I also find that cooking at home and eating meals together as a family helps me stay more in tune with what my body needs. What makes it harder, though, is the constant juggling of responsibilities. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, and I neglect my own needs in the rush to take care of everyone else. I've had to learn to be more intentional about rest and self-care, which isn't always easy when you're used to putting others first. But I've come to see that taking care of myself isn't selfish—it's the only way I can truly show up for my family and the work I do in the community.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Elizabeth Buchanan: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that have reminded me of the importance of listening to my body. About a year ago, I started experiencing more frequent migraines, which I hadn't dealt with in a long time. At first, I thought it was stress-related, and it was, but it turned out that I had developed a mild case of sinusitis that was contributing to the pain. I worked with a naturopath and made some changes to my diet and sleep habits, which helped manage it. Around the same time, I also had a minor flare-up of the back issues I've had since my graduate studies. I was doing a lot of bending and lifting with the kids, and one day I felt a sharp pain in my lower back. I saw my chiropractor, and with some adjustments and physical therapy, I was able to get back on track. These experiences made me more aware of how interconnected my physical health is with my emotional and spiritual well-being. I've since made a point to schedule regular check-ups and to take more time for rest, even if it means saying no to things that don't align with my health priorities. It's been a gentle reminder that taking care of myself is not just about being healthy—it's about being present for the people and things that matter most.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Honestly, there were moments when my health challenges did make things more difficult, especially with the demands of caring for two young children and keeping up with my volunteer work. There were days when the migraines left me feeling drained, and I had to cancel plans or take a step back from certain responsibilities. The back pain, too, made some tasks more challenging, like bending down to help the kids with their homework or carrying groceries. But what I've learned is that these moments aren't setbacks—they're reminders to slow down and reassess. I've had to become more intentional about pacing myself, asking for help when I need it, and not trying to do everything at once. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that taking care of my health isn't just about avoiding problems—it's about creating space to be fully present for my family and the work I do. In that way, it's actually strengthened my ability to care for my children and contribute to the community, because I'm more aware now of what my body and mind need to function at their best.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Elizabeth Buchanan: Over the past year, I've felt a deep sense of gratitude for the small, everyday moments that make life meaningful. There have been challenges, of course—health issues, the ongoing demands of raising two young children, and the ever-present tension between wanting to contribute to the community and needing to rest. But there's also been a quiet strength that has grown within me, a kind of resilience that comes from learning to listen to myself more deeply. I've found comfort in the routines I've built, like the morning meditations with the kids or the Sunday family meals, and I've come to see these as acts of love and care, not just habits. I've also felt a renewed sense of purpose in my work at the community center, especially as I've started to see the impact of the cultural exchange programs we've organized. It's humbling to realize how much I've grown over the past year—not just as a mother or a volunteer, but as someone who is more in tune with her own needs and values. I've learned that life isn't about perfection, but about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding beauty in the ordinary.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and daily routines are intertwined with the values and practices I've cultivated over the years. The shift toward mindfulness, whether in meditation with my children or in the way I approach my meals and rest, has become a quiet but powerful force in my life. It's not always easy to prioritize my own well-being, especially when I'm juggling the needs of my family and my work in the community. But I've come to see that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity. The challenges I've faced with my health, like the migraines and back pain, have been reminders that I need to listen more closely to my body and mind. In many ways, these experiences have deepened my understanding of what it means to live with intention and balance. I've learned that even small changes, like a family meal on Sunday or a few minutes of meditation each morning, can have a lasting impact on how I feel and how I show up for the people I love.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I think I've had moments of anxiety, especially during the times when I felt like I was juggling too many responsibilities or when I wasn't sure if I was making the right choices for my family and myself. There were periods when I questioned whether I was doing enough, whether I was being the kind of mother, wife, and community member I wanted to be. But I've come to see those feelings not as weaknesses, but as signs that I care deeply about the people and values in my life. I've started to approach anxiety with more compassion, using mindfulness and meditation to ground myself when I feel overwhelmed. I also talk to Rachel, my friend from graduate school, when I need support—she's been a great reminder that it's okay to not have all the answers. I've learned that vulnerability isn't something to be ashamed of; it's part of being human, and it's what connects us to each other in the most meaningful ways.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Elizabeth Buchanan: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and quiet moments of connection. David has been incredibly supportive, especially as I've navigated my health issues and the demands of raising two young children. He's taken on more responsibilities at home, whether it's helping with the kids' homework, cooking dinners, or even joining me at the community center for events. It's been a beautiful reminder of how partnership can look in everyday life—not just in grand gestures, but in the small, consistent ways we show up for each other. Clara and Liam have also been growing in ways that are both heartwarming and humbling. Clara is becoming more independent, more curious about the world, and more aware of the values we're trying to instill in her. Liam, though still young, has a way of reminding me of the importance of presence—how he can be so completely engaged in the moment, whether it's building a tower with blocks or watching the clouds pass by. There have been difficult days, of course, especially when I've been unwell or when life feels overwhelming, but I've seen how my family has leaned into each other, how we've found ways to support one another even when things aren't perfect. It's not always easy, but I feel deeply grateful for the love and resilience we've built together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Spirituality has been a cornerstone of my life, shaping not just my beliefs but the way I move through the world. When I was younger, I was raised in a very academic, almost rigid environment, where religion was more of a cultural backdrop than a lived experience. But when I was in Kyoto, studying at the monastery, I felt something shift inside me. It wasn't just about the rituals or the teachings—it was about the way of being, the quiet presence, the deep respect for all things. That's when I truly began to understand what Buddhism meant to me. It's not about escaping life's difficulties, but about embracing them with awareness and compassion. Now, as a mother, I see how that practice has influenced the way I parent, how I approach challenges, and how I try to model mindfulness for my children. I don't always get it right, but I believe that spirituality is about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding meaning in the ordinary. It's a path I continue to walk, not because I have all the answers, but because it helps me stay grounded in the midst of life's constant change.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Elizabeth Buchanan: I don't use social media in the way many people do—scrolling through feeds or comparing my life to others. For me, it's more about staying connected with specific people in meaningful ways. I have a small group of friends and family who I keep in touch with through occasional messages or video calls, especially my parents in Vienna and Aiko from Kyoto. I also follow a few spiritual teachers and cultural organizations that align with my values, but I try not to let those platforms consume too much of my time. I find that the more I'm present in the physical world—with my children, in my neighborhood, and in my practice—the less I feel the need to be online. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay updated on community events in Irvington and to share the occasional photo of the kids or the garden. It's not a big part of my life, but it does help me feel connected to the wider world in a way that doesn't distract me from what's most important.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Honestly, I haven't found myself turning to social media for support during tough times, though I can see how it might help others. For me, support has always come from the people I'm physically close to—my husband, my children, my friends like Rachel and Aiko, and the community here in Irvington. When I've struggled, whether with health issues or the weight of daily responsibilities, it's been the quiet conversations, the shared meals, or even just the presence of someone who listens without judgment that has carried me through. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can connect people across distances, especially for those who might not have the same kind of support system I'm lucky to have. I just try to use it mindfully, not as a crutch, but as a tool to stay in touch with the people who matter most.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how deeply my health and emotional well-being are intertwined with the rhythms of my daily life and the support I receive from those around me. The challenges I've faced—like the migraines and back pain—have been more than just physical discomfort; they've been reminders to slow down, to listen to my body, and to prioritize rest and self-care. These experiences have also brought me closer to understanding my own emotional landscape, especially the moments of anxiety that come with juggling so many responsibilities. I've learned that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and that vulnerability is not a weakness but a part of being human. My family, especially David, has been a steady source of support, and their presence has reminded me that I don't have to carry everything alone. In many ways, these past few months have deepened my sense of gratitude—for the small moments of connection, for the resilience that grows in the face of difficulty, and for the understanding that health and emotional well-being are not separate from the life I live, but are at its very core.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Elizabeth Buchanan: In the past year, I've noticed a shift in my emotional landscape—there's been less of the constant worry that used to creep in, especially around balancing everything I'm responsible for. I think part of that comes from the mindfulness practices I've integrated into my daily life, especially the breathing exercises I do with the kids in the mornings. It's taught me to pause, even for just a moment, before reacting to stress. I've also become more aware of how my emotional state is tied to my physical health, so when I take care of my body—through rest, movement, and nourishing food—it has a ripple effect on my mind. I've started journaling more, not just for reflection, but as a way to release things I might otherwise hold onto. And I've learned to ask for help more openly, whether it's from David, Rachel, or even the other volunteers at the community center. It's not that I don't still feel stress or worry—it's just that I now have tools to navigate it, and I'm more willing to lean on others when I need to. That, I think, has made all the difference.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Our biggest expenses last month were related to childcare, groceries, and a few unexpected home repairs. David and I have a modest income, mostly from his job as a software developer, and I don't earn a traditional salary, so we have to be careful with every dollar. The cost of childcare is the largest single expense—Liam is in a daycare that's not cheap, and Clara has after-school activities that add up. Groceries are another big one, especially since I try to cook meals with fresh, whole ingredients, which can be more expensive than processed foods. We also had to replace the water heater, which came out of our savings. It's not always easy, but we've learned to live within our means, prioritize what's essential, and find creative ways to stretch our budget. For example, we carpool with other parents to save on gas, and I've started growing some of our own herbs in the small garden behind our house. It's not about luxury—it's about making sure we can provide for our family while still leaving room for the things that matter most, like community involvement and time with each other.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Our household spent roughly around $3,200 last month, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Typically, we average between $2,800 and $3,000 per month. The increase was mainly due to the unexpected water heater repair, which cost about $600, and a few additional expenses related to Clara's after-school activities. Normally, our biggest expenses are childcare, groceries, and utilities. David's salary covers most of our needs, but we also rely on some savings and the occasional community assistance program for things like school supplies or cultural events. We've learned to be very intentional with our money, prioritizing what truly matters—like our children's education, our health, and our time together. It's not always easy, but we've found that living simply allows us to focus on the things that bring real fulfillment, rather than trying to keep up with material wants.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Elizabeth Buchanan: We rent our home. It's a small but cozy two-bedroom apartment in Irvington, just a few blocks from the community center where I volunteer. Rent is one of our more consistent expenses, and while it's not cheap, it's manageable because the neighborhood is walkable and we don't have to spend much on transportation. I actually love our apartment—it has a little garden space where I grow herbs and vegetables, which helps keep our food costs down. Renting has been a good choice for us, especially since we're still figuring out our long-term plans. David and I have talked about buying a home someday, but for now, renting gives us the flexibility we need, especially with the kids' schooling and our involvement in the community. It's not the most luxurious place, but it feels like home, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Elizabeth Buchanan: Over the past year, our bills have had their usual ups and downs, depending on the season and what's going on with the kids. In the winter, our heating bill tends to go up, and we've had to be more careful with our energy use, especially since we're trying to keep our carbon footprint low. In the summer, we use more electricity for the air conditioner, but we've also started using fans and natural ventilation to cut costs. School-related expenses also fluctuate—when the kids are in session, we have more costs for after-school activities, school supplies, and transportation. Then there are the holidays, which bring their own set of expenses, like gifts, special meals, and sometimes even travel. Last Christmas, for example, we had a small family trip to visit my parents in Vienna, which added a few hundred dollars to our budget. On the flip side, there are months where things are quieter—like in the summer when the kids are on break, and we don't have as many scheduled activities. We've learned to budget for these fluctuations by setting aside a little extra each month, just in case. It's not always perfect, but it helps us stay grounded and focused on what really matters.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how deeply my family and emotional well-being are intertwined with the support systems I've built around me. Talking about my family reminded me of how much love and resilience we've cultivated together, especially during the challenges I've faced with my health and the demands of daily life. It's comforting to know that David, Clara, and Liam are my anchors, and that their presence gives me strength even on my toughest days. When I considered how I use social media, it became clear to me that I don't need it to feel connected or supported—what matters most is the genuine, face-to-face connection I have with the people in my life. I also see now how my emotional coping strategies, like mindfulness, journaling, and asking for help, have helped me navigate stress and anxiety with more grace. These insights have deepened my gratitude for the people and practices that sustain me, and they remind me that I don't have to face life's challenges alone.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I do save, though not in the way most people might expect. We have a small emergency fund tucked away in a savings account, which we've built up over the years by being mindful of our spending and prioritizing what truly matters. I also practice a kind of 'spiritual saving'—investing time and energy into things that nourish my family and community, like volunteering, teaching, and growing our own food. I think of saving as more than just money; it's about creating space for the things that bring meaning to life. That said, I'm not perfect at it. There are times when I feel like we're just scraping by, and I worry about the future. But I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about hoarding—it can be about being intentional, about making choices that reflect our values, even when resources are limited. It's a practice, just like meditation or parenting, and one that I'm still learning how to do well.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Elizabeth Buchanan: In the last year, my saving has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. We've been building up our emergency fund slowly, knowing that life can be unpredictable—especially with two young children and the occasional home repair or medical expense. I also save in a more intangible way, by investing in experiences that matter to us, like cultural events, family trips, or even just quiet evenings at home with a good book. I think of saving as a kind of spiritual practice too—being mindful of what we need, what we can do without, and what truly adds value to our lives. It's not about accumulating wealth, but about creating a foundation that allows us to live with intention and grace, even when things aren't perfect.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Buchanan: My occupation, if I were to define it in traditional terms, would be a combination of homemaker, volunteer, and cultural educator. While I don't have a formal job with a company or organization, the work I do at home and in the community is just as meaningful, if not more so, than any office job I might have had. As a homemaker, my duties include managing the household, caring for my children, preparing meals, and maintaining a sense of balance and calm in our home life. But it's not just about the practical tasks—it's about creating a nurturing environment where my children can grow, learn, and feel loved. At the community center, I help organize cultural exchange programs, teach language classes, and facilitate discussions on topics like mindfulness and intercultural understanding. These programs are deeply personal to me, as they tie back to my own journey of learning and adapting between different cultures. The most important activities for me are the ones that foster connection—whether it's through teaching, volunteering, or simply being present for my family. I think of this work as a kind of spiritual practice, one that requires patience, compassion, and a deep commitment to living with intention.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I don't measure my work in hours the way most people do, but if I had to estimate, I'd say I'm working around 40 to 50 hours a week, though it's spread out in different ways throughout the day. Some of that time is spent at the community center, helping with programs and events, and some of it is spent at home—managing the household, caring for the kids, and making sure we have meals on the table. It's not always easy to quantify, because a lot of it is invisible work, the kind that doesn't show up on a timesheet or a paycheck. But I think about it this way: every hour I spend with my children, every conversation I have with a volunteer, every moment I bring mindfulness into our daily lives—it's all part of the same kind of work, just in different forms. I don't know if that makes sense, but I feel like it's the most honest way to describe it.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Elizabeth Buchanan: No, I haven't had more than one job or business in the traditional sense, but I do see my roles as overlapping in ways that aren't always obvious. While David's work as a software developer is his primary source of income, I've taken on a few side projects that align with my interests in cultural exchange and mindfulness. For example, I occasionally lead small meditation workshops for local parents and teachers, and I've been collaborating with a few neighbors to start a community garden that also serves as a space for intercultural dialogue. These aren't paid positions in the way most people think of work, but they are extensions of the same values and passions that drive me. I think of them as part of the same journey—whether I'm teaching a language class, helping a neighbor plant herbs, or simply being present for my children, it all feels like work that matters. It's not about the hours or the paycheck, but about the impact, however small, that I can have on the people and community around me.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, I realize how deeply my emotional well-being and financial stability are connected to the support systems I've built in my life. Talking about my stress, coping strategies, and how I manage my household has reminded me of the importance of balance—not just in my daily routines, but in how I approach challenges with both my mind and my heart. I've come to see that emotional resilience is not something I have to achieve alone; it's something that grows through the love and presence of my family, the kindness of my friends, and the small, intentional choices I make every day. At the same time, managing our household budget and expenses has shown me how much I value simplicity and intentionality in life. It's not about having more, but about being mindful of what truly matters—our health, our time together, and the ways we can contribute to each other and our community. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for the life I have, even in its imperfections, and have reminded me that I am not just surviving, but learning to thrive in the way that feels most authentic to me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Elizabeth Buchanan: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month, though that includes David's salary, any freelance work he might have done, and the occasional stipend from the community center for special events or programs I help organize. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and some of the things that matter most to us—like cultural experiences, family time, and keeping our home comfortable. I think of it as a kind of quiet abundance, not because we have more than we need, but because we've learned to value what we have and make it work for us. It's not always easy, but I feel grateful for the stability we've built, even if it's not the kind of wealth that's measured in numbers alone.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Elizabeth Buchanan: To be honest, I don't have a traditional workplace in the way most people do, but if I had to describe it, I would say my workplace is wherever I am with my family, in our home, or at the community center. I've been in this role—of homemaker, volunteer, and cultural educator—for nearly seven years now, since we moved here to Irvington and I started volunteering at the center. The benefits of this work aren't the kind you find on a company brochure, but they are real and deeply meaningful. I get to spend time with my children every day, which is the greatest gift I can imagine. I also get to connect with others in the community, to share ideas, and to create spaces where people can learn from one another. There's no paid vacation or sick leave in the traditional sense, but I do have the freedom to rest when I need to, to slow down, and to be present in the way that truly matters. I think of the benefits as being more about time, connection, and purpose—things that can't always be measured in dollars or hours, but that shape the kind of life I want to live for my family and my community.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Elizabeth Buchanan: My relationships at work, if I can call the community center a workplace, are deeply rooted in mutual respect and shared purpose. I don't have a manager in the traditional sense, but there's a small group of people who lead the center, and I work closely with them on planning events and programs. I have a lot of trust and admiration for them—they're passionate about what they do, and they've been incredibly supportive of my ideas, especially when it comes to cultural exchange and mindfulness. As for my coworkers, they're like family. We've been through a lot together—late nights organizing events, long days in the garden, and the occasional moment of frustration when things don't go as planned. But what keeps us going is the shared belief that what we do matters. I feel seen and valued here, not just for what I contribute, but for who I am. It's a different kind of relationship than I had in more traditional workplaces, but it's one that feels more authentic, more connected to the heart of what I want to do in life.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Elizabeth Buchanan: My work schedule is quite flexible, which is one of the things I appreciate most about it. Unlike traditional jobs with set hours and strict deadlines, my days are shaped by the needs of my family and the rhythms of the community center. Some weeks I might be more involved with events and programs, which can mean longer hours on certain days, while other weeks are quieter, allowing me more time to rest or focus on personal practice. I also have the freedom to adjust my schedule as needed—whether it's staying late at the center to finish a project or leaving early if I need to be home for the kids. That flexibility is both a gift and a responsibility. It means I have to be intentional about how I use my time, but it also allows me to be present in the ways that matter most. I think of it as a kind of balance, one that requires constant attention, but one that feels deeply aligned with who I am and what I value most in life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Overall, I feel a mix of gratitude and awareness about our financial situation. We're not wealthy, but we're not struggling either. It's a life that requires intention and mindfulness, which I think has actually been a gift in many ways. I've learned to appreciate what we have, to find joy in the simple things, and to be present for the people who matter most. There are moments when I worry about the future, especially with the rising costs of living and the unpredictable nature of life with two young children. But I've also come to see that financial stability isn't just about numbers—it's about the freedom to choose how we live, to prioritize what's important, and to build a life that feels meaningful. I'm not sure if I'd trade this for a more conventional career with a higher salary, because I think the way we live now—rooted in community, connection, and purpose—has given us something far more valuable than material wealth.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Elizabeth Buchanan: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father was a professor of philosophy at a university in Vienna, so he had a stable job with a salary, though it wasn't always easy to make ends meet, especially when I was younger. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a translator, which was more flexible but also less predictable. She often had to take on multiple projects at once, which meant her income could fluctuate. I remember times when we had to be very careful with our money, but my parents always made sure that my brother and I had what we needed for school and basic necessities. What I noticed growing up was that their work wasn't just about earning a living—it was also about their passion. My father loved teaching, and my mother found deep satisfaction in the way language could connect people. I think that's something I carry with me today, the idea that work can be meaningful even if it's not always glamorous or well-paid.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Buchanan: My father's job was as a professor of philosophy at the University of Vienna, and my mother worked as a translator, often for academic and cultural institutions. Their most important activities were deeply tied to their passions. My father's duties involved teaching, writing, and engaging in philosophical debates—both in the classroom and in the broader academic community. He had a way of making complex ideas accessible, and I remember how he would come home from work and sit with us, discussing everything from ancient Greek thought to modern existentialism. My mother, on the other hand, spent her days translating texts between languages, often working on projects that bridged cultures. She had a particular love for translating religious and literary works, and I think that's where my own interest in language and spirituality began. What I admired most about both of them was how they approached their work not just as a means of survival, but as a way of contributing to the world in a meaningful way. They taught me that even the most intellectual or quiet forms of work can have a deep impact, and that's something I carry with me in everything I do today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Elizabeth Buchanan: My father worked for the University of Vienna, which was a public institution, and my mother worked for a variety of cultural and academic organizations, often as a freelance translator. Their work wasn't about making a lot of money—it was about contributing to something larger than themselves. My father taught philosophy, which meant he spent a lot of time in lectures, writing papers, and engaging with students and colleagues in deep discussions. He also published books and articles, which was both a professional duty and a personal passion. My mother, on the other hand, worked with texts—translating everything from historical documents to literary works. She had a way of making language feel alive, and I remember her talking about how each word carried a kind of weight, a history, and a meaning that couldn't always be captured directly. She often worked from home, which gave her a lot of flexibility, but also meant she had to be disciplined to meet deadlines. What I learned from both of them was that work doesn't have to be about prestige or salary—it can be about purpose, about the way you show up for the world, and about the quiet, steady impact you have on others, even if it's not always seen or celebrated.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Elizabeth Buchanan: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here in Irvington, raising my children in the same neighborhood that has become our home. I hope they're growing into thoughtful, compassionate people who feel connected to the world around them, just as I did when I was their age. I hope that my work at the community center continues to make a difference, that the cultural exchange programs we've started have grown into something that brings people together in meaningful ways. I also hope that I'm still finding time for myself, for my practice, and for the quiet moments that remind me why I chose this path. I don't know if my life will look the same in every way—maybe I'll have more responsibilities, or maybe I'll have more time to explore the things that bring me joy. But I hope that whatever happens, I'm still living with intention, still learning, and still finding ways to contribute to the people and community I love.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Elizabeth Buchanan: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection with my family, with my community, and with the deeper truths that guide me. I value the quiet moments, like the way the morning light filters through the trees or the sound of my children laughing as they play in the garden. I value the lessons I've learned through my parents, my teachers, and my own journey—lessons about resilience, about compassion, and about the importance of showing up for the people you love. I also value the way my spiritual practice has shaped me, not just as a mother or a volunteer, but as someone who tries to live with awareness and intention. In a world that often moves so fast, I find meaning in the slow, steady rhythm of life—the way we grow, the way we care for each other, and the way we keep learning, even when the path isn't always clear.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45, I realize how much my sense of purpose and fulfillment comes from the non-traditional roles I play in my life. Talking about our household income and how we make ends meet reminded me of the importance of living intentionally, not just for financial stability, but for the values that truly matter—like family, community, and connection. It also made me think about how my work, though not defined by a traditional job, is deeply meaningful. Being a mother, a volunteer, and a cultural educator is not just about duties or responsibilities—it's about the impact I have on the people around me, and the way I contribute to something larger than myself. I see now how my relationships at the community center, though different from corporate workplaces, are just as rich and meaningful. They are built on trust, shared purpose, and a deep commitment to what we do. It's a reminder that work doesn't have to be measured in hours or paychecks—it can be measured in the love, care, and connection we give to others, and in the way we show up for the life we've chosen to live.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It has allowed me to look back at the path I've walked—from my childhood in Vienna, to the crossroads in Kyoto that shaped my spiritual and cultural identity, to the life I've built here in Irvington with my family and community. I see now how every choice, every challenge, and every moment of connection has led me to where I am today. It's not a perfect story, nor is it one of grand achievements, but it's one of growth, resilience, and purpose. I've come to understand that my life is not just about the roles I play—mother, volunteer, cultural educator—but about the values I hold, the relationships I nurture, and the quiet, intentional ways I show up for the people and world around me. This reflection has reminded me that my story is still unfolding, and that the most meaningful parts of it are not always the ones I plan, but the ones I live with openness, love, and gratitude.
